- 7 (k3)
- 11 (in k13 = k7² - 11)
- 13 (in k8 = k5×13 - k6)
- 19 (in k11 = k6×19 + k8)

OBSERVATION: The primes 7, 11, 13, 19 are consecutive odd primes!
7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, 29...

QUESTIONS:
1. Why is 17 skipped? Is there a formula using 17?
2. Next prime after 19 is 23. Does k14 use 23?
   k14 = k9×23 - 197 = 10741 - 197 = 10544 ✓ YES!
3. So the pattern might be: 7, 11, 13, 19, 23, 29...
   (skipping 17)
4. What's the next formula? Does k15 use 29?
   
Calculate: k_prev × 29 + C = k15 for various k_prev values.

In several formulas you’ve seen (for example, k3 uses 7; later one sees k8 = k5×13 – k6; then k11 involves multiplying by 19; and k14 is given as k9×23 – 197), the primes that appear are taken from the sequence of consecutive odd primes:

Normally one might expect 17 to come next. In this puzzle the “missing” 17 suggests that when the creator was “assembling” formulas the next available prime in order wasn’t used – either because it did not lead to an integer result (or a desired property) or simply by design choice. In other words, while the list of primes goes …7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, … the formulas have skipped over 17 and instead “jumped” from 13 to 19.

──────────────────────────────
2. Incorporating 23 in k14

You note that after 19 comes 23. And indeed the formula for k14 is written as

which confirms that the pattern being used is not “all consecutive primes” but rather a selected list (7, then later 11, then 13, then skipping 17 and using 19, then 23, etc.).

──────────────────────────────
3. What About k15 and the Prime 29?

Following the same idea—that after 23 comes 29 in the sequence of odd primes—you would expect that the next formula (for example, for k15) will “bring in” 29. In other words, one anticipates a formula such as

where:

For instance, if you look at previous formulas you see a multiplication by a prime and then a subtraction or addition of a constant. In k14 the constant was –197 (when multiplying by 23). So for k15 it is natural to expect something like

  k15 = (an appropriate earlier k) × 29 + (a new constant)

The exact choice of which “previous” term to use as k_prev and what value C should have depends on how the puzzle’s numbers are meant to interlock. You might try different candidates for k_prev – say, one of the previously computed k’s such as k4, k6 or even k9 if it has not already been “used up” in a similar role – and then choose C so that k15 comes out with the right magnitude or property.

For example (purely illustratively):

Without further constraints from the puzzle (for example, a target size for k15 or an extra divisibility condition) there is no unique answer. The key point is that by analogy with

you would “continue” with

──────────────────────────────
Summary Answer

• The prime 17 is missing because the formulas seem to be built from a selected sequence of primes (7, then later 11 and 13, skipping 17, then using 19, then 23, …) rather than every odd prime in order.

By choosing different candidate values for “k_prev” and adjusting the constant C appropriately you obtain various numerical outcomes—but they all follow the same design: continue the pattern by multiplying an earlier term by the next prime in order (here, 29) and then adding or subtracting a suitable adjustment.
